The is no such thing as 'absolute pitch. Assigning a name to particular pitch (number of vibrations per second) is a social construct, and has varied widely throughout early modern history. One of the problems people with so-called 'perfect pitch' may need to deal with is in historically informed performance of 'baroque and early classical music. There is then a need to adjust to various pitches from A-392 and A-409, the most used 'baroque' pitch A-415, Handel's tuning fork A-422.5, and the typical Mozart era pitch A-425/430. It is also necessary to adjust to a wide range of different unequal 'temperaments' e.g. Werkmeister, or Valotti. For the historically informed performance of music from the period 1600-1790, so called 'perfect pitch' A-440/445, with equal temperament tuning, is useless and a huge disadvantage; but if one wants to play music from the baroque and early classical period in the anachronistic style of the 1950s on modern instruments, modern pitch is  good.

There are people who try to convince that adults cannot learn absolute pitch but their reasoning is persuasive and not deductive!!

Audio frequencies have many many properties and they influence matter (particles, molecules cells etc.) and matter can identify different audio frequencies they change their 'behaviour' accordingly.
An adult IS made of matter and how would it be reasonable to say that we don't have the ability to learn to recognise them?

A word from a natural language has an external pattern and an internal pattern (within our brain) it is a one to one mapping. Just like if we can think of a word then we can speak that word and if we hear a word that is in our internal word bank then the meaning is recalled. Words have complex patterns hence they are easily distinguishable.

If you can 'listen' for the pattern in a pitch then you can learn to amplify that pattern through familiarity. But what exactly should you be listening for? that is what learning to recognise a pitch involves.

For me, it has always been centered around an internal tone that I constantly have with me; sort of my personal tone. I'm generally accurate to within 1 to 3Hz or "cents". Polyphonic combinations are a bit different as they are very geometric for me. I was told I had perfect pitch from my guitar lessons instructor in college during the fall semester of 2017 when I couldn't tell him the name of a chord, but I could tell him all of the names of the notes in the chord he strummed. Then he tested it out by hitting random notes on a piano and I named them all. He then told another music teacher at the school who plays saxophone and when I walked into the band hall after another lesson he told me to name a note from his saxophone and I named it. Then other students got exited and asked me to name notes from their instruments, which I did. Then every so often they'd hit random piano keys and wait until I named them. Another music teacher at the school figured out I had perfect pitch when I was the only one naming keys. The way I did it was by being bored one day in the spring of 2016. Being in my school's Jazz Ensemble for the first time because the professor needed a guitarist and he recognized me from the school's music club. Sometime after the first day I was intimidated, so I went home and hit all notes on the keyboard at home and said the name of the note (sharps and flats also) then went upstairs and strummed all of the notes on my guitar and named them. Then I did it a second time on the guitar, except during the second time, with each note, I thought of the first word that came to mind with each note. So whenever I hear a note, I hear the word I associated it with and then I name the note. And that's how I learned perfect pitch.

Just thought I'd share my story of achieving an absolute pitch.

Before the age of 12, I had no desire to learn, perform or create music. But it was a time when I started hearing about DJs. So it quickly became a bit of an obsession with me and I started learning DJing as a way to perform music. Slowly but surely, playing other people's music became more boring with each day and I realized that it would be great to have your own music. And with that thought, I began my journey to becoming a sound-producer and engineer.

Since creating a musical piece in a modern way often comes with a regular repetition, I couldn't help myself but notice that I could recall certain parts of the composition in my head. What made me wonder is that with this ability I could not only "listen back" but modify sounds in my mind the way they could be modified by different audio plugins and tools.

In a parallel to that, I also began experimenting with my voice. In other words, singing and beatboxing. One day I was strolling down the street, deep in conversation with a fellow musician. We were debating over a piece of music and at one moment I casually a passage without "tuning" myself. Then my friend wanted to repeat that passage with a smartphone keys app and when he played it with the original key he noticed that I actually sang it pitch perfectly. He asked me whether or not I have an absolute pitch. Naturally, I told him I don't have one.

But cases like that started to repeat and one day a friend tested me. I could always sing whatever note I was asked to sing but I was struggling to listen back and guess a note correctly. With singing, I felt like I've been recalling a pitch from the back of my mind and matching it with my voice, but with listening it was more of a like trying to find a pitch one semitone at a time.

A few years had passed and now in 99.9% of the cases, I can not only guess a note correctly, I can tell by how much is it off. I can also tell a difference between different A4 references and types of tuning. In general, it took me 9 years to develop such a skill, the only drawback being unable to enjoy the music without analysing it, guessing keys, etc., etc.

Learned to play recorder early in life. It is an instrument that is very close to the range of the human voice singing (not a big range of notes). Back in those days can tell the different notes apart. Not because of perfect pitch but because of good memory of having seen the sheet music and the Key Signature. Also knowing the fingerings of particular notes I can watch a which hole a performer's finger pressed and determine visually he played an A or B.
When it comes to telling the Key a song is in... in the beginning the music teacher taught a few easy songs but not enough music theory so wouldn't be able say a song with 2 sharps is in D. This came later in high school with a violin teacher.
When it comes to Pop songs, certain ones that I've seen the score I can tell the Key in so many sharps or flats (not by listening alone) like "Waterloo" & "Mama Mia" by Abba in D, "Chiquitita" & "Fernando" in A.

Perfect pitch can also be lost. I started playing the piano at age 6. It took a music teacher who was teaching me clarinet at age 12 to notice - in theory tests - that he could play any note on the piano and I could name it instantly. No-one else in the class could, and I became a bit of a celebrity in the school for it. Stories like "she can even tell you the note of the aircraft flying overhead" (not really true...) spread. I always found it tougher with instruments other than the piano, but could usually manage it. With voice, I could usually get it right, or at least very close.
But now, it's gone. Not completely; sometimes I will absolutely know that note you played on the piano is a C, or whatever. But very often I will be quite unsure. And it's not even a proximity thing; sometimes I might be unsure if a note is (for example) a Bb or an Eb, but I think it is one of them.
Maybe it's a result of not being tested, and not testing myself on it. Maybe it's because I played a piano that was out of tune for a while (that is, incidentally, very difficult if you have perfect pitch, because you keep thinking you're playing wrong notes). Perhaps I should try to train myself again and see if it comes back.

Perfect pitch is completely arbitrary. Not EVERYONE tunes to A440 as a pitch center. For instance, someone trained in "perfect pitch" at A440 would find, say, Machine Head confusing, as the guitars are tuned to B, PLUS 40 cents sharp (just shy of a quarter tone), or scales outside 12 TET. They're essentially locked into the western convention of 12 TET tuned to A440 from childhood programming. Impressive what they can do, but hardly the limitations of where notes can reside and the intervals between.

The supposition that perfect pitch cannot be learned by an adult is totally false. It is just a matter of practice. There are numerous examples of adults acquiring this capability. In fact, I would go so far as to say this is wholly unlike most of your videos and almost irresponsible in its claim. This is one of these bizarre myths that lingers like "language acquisition is superior in young children". In fact, this is also totally false. Adults learn languages much faster and more efficiently than children and can learn to speak any human language with fluency provided they work hard enough- it just feels like more work as an adult. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0010027715000621 Further, there is significant evidence that all children are born with perfect pitch and as one neglects the ability, one loses it. https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/1323575/Babies-tune-into-the-art-of-talking-with-gift-of-perfect-pitch.html Finally, I think the most conclusive piece of evidence here is actually a study on monkeys that were born red green colorblind and then administered a gene therapy correcting this flaw. They did not immediately see red and green though the photoreceptor expression was readily observed. They, in fact, had to be taught to see it. https://www.nature.com/news/2009/090916/full/news.2009.921.html The precision of our senses is not innate and baring physical or cognitive disability can be vastly sharpened with practice. None of the papers cited in your video in fact endeavor to prove that AP cannot be learned- in fact, they merely state an oft parroted conjecture while studying something that is only tangential. Finally, I'll leave you with an interesting internet adventure where an adult acquires essentially perfect pitch in 16 hours. https://medium.com/@maxdeutsch/how-i-developed-perfect-pitch-in-30-days-at-24-years-old-7e2e78b8c26b

Physics Girl
I think that your explanation of the difference between absolute and relative pitch isn't complete. Absolute pitch means that you can identify any tone on any instrument and any object, like you showed. So far so good. If you can however identify any tone on your own instrument but not on other instruments or objects, for all octaves or a few octaves of your instrument, then you still only have a relative pitch. If you can find all the notes on several instruments but you need to take a reference note to find it (a note from a song or a note which you can reproduce immediately (for example C3/C4 on the piano) then you still only have a relative pitch. Relative pitch can go a lot further than just recognizing a difference between notes and while it probably is impossible for adults to develop a perfect pitch it certainly is possible for adults to learn to recognize any note on the instrument they play, including tritones or even more notes which are being played at the same time. As a matter of fact, even people who have a perfect pitch need to do ear training to optimally use their ability. For example, somebody who has got a well trained relative pitch might be able to recognize intervals (even spread out on several octaves) without being able to tell which notes he exactly hears while somebody with perfect pitch might hear the notes but can't easily identify the intervals. To become a great musician or composer you don't need perfect pitch. I recommend to watch Rick Beato (a professional musician who has got a Youtube channel) his explanation on relative pitch vs. absolute pitch. He demonstrates it with his son who has both a perfect pitch and an extremely well trained 'ear' (obviously it is the brain which makes the difference and not the ear). There also are people who have a perfect pitch but they can't sing the notes correctly without practice while there are people with just a well developed perfect pitch who can sing the notes perfectly.

I think that people might get the idea of your explanation of relative pitch that it is a lot less extensive/useful than what it can be. Relative pitch is an extremely broad concept which covers people who couldn't get close to singing with the correct notes if their lives depend on it to people who can transcribe anything they hear and recognize any note with some tools they developed (taking a reference note, that might even be the same note from your memory). Even though you only have a relative pitch, with practice you could learn to sing directly correctly while just reading the notes or based upon nothing else but your own memory of listening to the song, you don't need a perfect pitch for that. It doesn't have to be like you showed with your friend: roughly singing the correct intervals but transposed. Though it easily happens to people who don't have a perfect pitch but a reasonably welll developed relative pitch. Sometimes that is a good thing, if you have to sing an octave lower or higher.

The little higher frequencies in instruments and such are called harmonics. Additive synthesis is the concept of building different wave shapes by adding harmonics (sine waves). This can then be modulated afterwards among the line with fm filters envelopes and so forth. FM or frequency modulation uses a waveform like sine to manipulate the pitch over time of a carrier signal. Crank up the frequency of the modulation wave and all sorts of pitch bending and strange sounds come out which is why in many cases if you play a note on a synth it can be completely off of what note that key represents.

Perfect pitch for musicians can be a curse - it really depends on the kind of music you play.

For example if I play cello music with a piano and have perfect pitch I am locked into equal temperament tuning - which is the modern way keyboards are tuned and is an out of tune compromise to make the piano 'work' in all keys. ('Real' tuning depends on the physics of the harmonic series - maybe worth a video 😂)

If I play in a string quartet I have to adjust the tuning of notes to make a consistent harmonic language - for someone with 'perfect' pitch this is going to be painful.

Even worse if I play with a baroque orchestra they will play at different tuning pitches from the baroque era - commonly (but not always) a note written as A would sound to modern 'perfect' pitch as G#. Reading notes at one pitch and hearing them at another pitch is really difficult (if not impossible) for many musicians with 'perfect pitch'.

Finally many instruments retune parts of their instruments to different pitches - eg. Bach asks the cellist to tune down their A string to G for the 5th solo suite. However the music is written as though the tuning is normal. That means the A in the music sounds as a G. Someone with perfect pitch pitch will have a permanent mismatch between what they see, play and hear. This example is relatively easy to deal with (use normal tuning and write out the music is correct pitch) but some pieces (eg. the sonata by Kodaly which retunes two strings would be unplayable - some notes in normal tuning would not even exist on the instrument).

People with relative pitch can deal with all of these anomalies but people with perfect pitch can find them very disturbing and restrictons on the repertoire they play.

Surely whether you have perfect pitch is just a question of degree.

The set of notes we have is about 60 points in the range between 30Hz and 4000 Hz.

But what if we considered a set that only had 3 distinct notes: {400Hz, 1000Hz, and 4000 Hz}. If one of these 3 notes was then played, then surely you would be able to know which one it is without a reference. You would have perfect pitch of degree 3, no problem.

These people who have 'perfect pitch' have perfect pitch to a degree of 60.
And people who don't have 'perfect pitch' actually do have it, just to a degree somewhere between 3 and 60.

So maybe a method to learn to be 'perfect pitch' is to start with a small set of notes, get perfect with them. Then over time introduce new notes to your set, until you get perfect with all 60 notes.

Pitch has only been standardised very recently so that A is 440hz etc. When I tried to work out how to play Rock this Town by The Stray Cats, using the original recording as a reference, I had to de-tune the guitar down a quarter step (between 2 notes) to make sense of it. The deviation in pitch of the original recording was probably due to the musicians tuning their instruments (guitar and double-bass) with each other rather than using a fixed pitch reference such as a piano or tuner. People with perfect pitch are able to distinguish such deviations in pitch quite naturally. Those with good relative pitch are only able to tune the instrument to itself using a particular string as a reference. Fascinating subject, thanks Diana!

At this point I'd say it is at best inconclusive as to whether absolute pitch can be taught.

I'd say (like, to help others imagine what it's like), that perfect pitch is really close to what you experience when reading: i mean, when you read, you see the words, and somehow they sound inside your head, as if someone was speaking them.
Perfect pitch is the same, but with notes: you hear the note, and you somehow hear also the name of that note, as if someone was reading it inside your head.

And that's exactly why it's so hard for us to play with an instrument that sounds offset from the way it should: it's like if someone was telling you his phone number, but also showing you some numbers at the same time, which are not the ones he's saying (and you can't just close your eyes, cause it's inside your head ahahah). It just makes you crazy.

Dianna, I'm surprised to see you didn't mention a critical physics factor - that the wavelengths in air of musical notes are comparable to the sizes of the instruments that produce them. Bigger but not hugely bigger though, roughly 1.5-4x larger (for the human voice, 10-15x).  So this means you can't ignore the interaction of the sound wave with the instrument itself, what it's made of, what shape it is.  That's where timbre comes from (and the distinguishing characteristics of the speaker of language or singer of songs, in the case of the voice).  If the wavelengths were very much larger than the instrument (like 1000x), the distinctiveness of a keyboard C note from a violin C note would be very much smaller.

I was a professional classical musician and let me tell you, people with perfect pitch are INSUFFERABLE. Not only that but they are hindered because pitch is totally and completely arbitrary. Good luck playing music outside equal temperament. "1.05946, 12th root of 2, Amen." Great video though. Loved it as I'm a tuning nerd.

Also, being able to pull pitches out of the air doesn't necessarily mean perfect pitch. Many musicians without perfect pitch do have reference pitches they can always pull out of the air (A440 is and easy one for most). If you hear something enough you can mimic it for a long period of time. Perfect pitch is a little more than just referring to songs or using your memory of pitches to determine pitches.
